questions.text: A child presented with pain in the forearm following a trauma. The radiograph of the forearm reveal the findings as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Galeazzi fracture

 

Explanation:

 

GALEAZZI FRACTURE-DISLOCATION

 

  • Fracture of distal third of radius with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint, along with damage to interosseous membrane and triangular fibrocartilage complex
  • A treatment regimen of closed reduction and cast immobilization has a high rate of unsatisfactory results.
  • Open reduction and internal fixation with plate is the treatment of choice in adult.

 

 

Monteggia and Galeazzi Fractures:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Colle’s fracture. Colles’s fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corti-cocancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women, as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in extension. It is one of the most common fractures in elderly. Most Colles fractures can be successfully treated nonoperatively, and cast (hand-shaking cast) is applied on opposite forces to displacement. Complications include finger stiffness (most common), malunion (2nd most common) leading to dinner fork deformity. Colles’s fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.

 

Dinner fork deformity

 

 

Reduction and application of Hand-shaking cast

 

Option B. Smith’s fracture. A Smith fracture is a break to the end of the radius. The end part of the bone, which forms part of the wrist joint, is displaced or angled in the direction of the palm of the hand. Often, this injury occurs by a fall to the back of a flexed wrist but can occur in any fall to an outstretched hand. Smith fracture is treated by close reduction and immobilization in long arm (above elbow) cast with forearm in supination and wrist in extension (dorsiflexion).

 

 

Option C. Monteggia fracture. Fractures between the proximal third of the ulna and the base of olecranon combined with dislocation of the proximal radioulnar joint. The clue to successful treatment is to restore the length of the fractured ulna; only then can the dislocated joint be fully reduced and remain stable. In adults, treatment is reduction and fixation. In children, treatment is reduction and cast application. Posterior interosseous nerve has been most commonly injured nerve in association with Monteggia fracture dislocation because it takes a turn around radial head and is injured with its dislocation. This causes paralysis of thumb and finger extensors.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image in the question reveals a Galeazzi fracture of the forearm.

questions.text:
Arrange lung hilar structures from anterior to posterior:

 

1. Primary bronchus

2. Bronchial artery

3. Pulmonary vein

4. Pulmonary artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3, 4, 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Lung hilar structures are arranged from the anterior to posterior in the order:

 

  • Pulmonary vein
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Primary bronchus
  • Bronchial artery

 

The superior vena cava and right atrium are seen in front of the right root and terminal part of the azygos vein superiorly. The hilar structures are arranged from the superior to inferior as:

 

  • Superior lobar bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: DOC for fasciola hepatica: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triclabendazole

 

Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for treating Fasciola hepatica (liver fluke) infections because:

 

  • It is the latest and most effective drug available
  • Has excellent activity against both immature and mature flukes
  • Single dose treatment is often effective
  • Well-tolerated with minimal side effects
  • WHO recommended first-line treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Albendazole:

 

  • More effective against nematodes
  • Limited efficacy against liver flukes
  • Not recommended as first-line therapy for fascioliasis

 

Option C. Mebendazole:

 

  • Primarily used for treating intestinal nematodes
  • Poor absorption and bioavailability
  • Not effective against liver flukes

 

Option D. Praziquantel:

 

  • While effective against most trematodes
  • Has poor efficacy against Fasciola species
  • Used mainly for schistosomiasis and other fluke infections

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for treating Fasciola hepatica (liver fluke) infections.

questions.text: What is the volume of the prostate in normal adult males? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20cc

 

Explanation:

 

The volume of the prostate in normal adult males is 20cc.

 

The volume of the prostate gland in normal adult males can vary depending on age and other factors. However, on average, the volume of the prostate gland in an adult male is around 20-30 cubic centimeters (cc) or milliliters (mL).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical volume of the prostate in a normal adult male is around 20cc

choices.text: Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey
Light blue → Lavender → Red → Grey
Grey → Red → Light blue → Lavender
Red → Lavender → Grey → Light blue

questions.text: The phlebotomist needs to collect samples from a patient for various tests. Among the options provided, which sequence of blood collection for testing ensures that the sample remains uncontaminated, considering the additives present in the collection tubes? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey

 

The Clinical & Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) has provided a recommended color sequence for collecting multiple venous and/or arterial blood samples from a single patient: Yellow, Pink, Light Blue, Red, Green, Lavender, And Grey.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The accurate color sequence for the blood collection tubes is as follows:

 

Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey

questions.text: Blood supply for the red shaded area in the given image is a branch of which artery? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vertebral artery

 

 

 

The red shaded area in the given image indicates a portion of the lateral medulla. The blood supply to this area is provided by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery. This area is typically involved in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

 

  • Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA): This artery is a branch of the vertebral artery and supplies the lateral part of the medulla and the inferior part of the cerebellum. Damage to this artery can lead to lateral medullary syndrome, characterized by various neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior cerebellar artery: This artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and does not supply the lateral medulla.

 

Option B. Posterior cerebral artery: This artery primarily supplies the occipital lobe and parts of the temporal lobe, not the lateral medulla.

 

Option D. Basilar artery: While the basilar artery gives rise to the superior cerebellar artery and the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, it does not directly supply the lateral medulla. The vertebral arteries, which form the basilar artery, give rise to PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery, supplies the lateral medulla. Damage to this artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

questions.text: The sulcus located deep to the marked structure is? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stem of the lateral sulcus

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image points to the region where the parietal lobe and temporal lobe meet. This region is associated with the lateral sulcus, also known as the Sylvian fissure. The stem of the lateral sulcus is located deep to this marked structure, separating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central sulcus: Incorrect. The central sulcus separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe and is not located in the region marked in the image.

 

Option C. Inferior frontal sulcus: Incorrect. This sulcus is found on the lateral surface of the frontal lobe and does not correspond to the marked region.

 

Option D. Superior temporal sulcus: Incorrect. This sulcus runs parallel to the lateral sulcus on the temporal lobe, but it is not deep to the marked structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The stem of the lateral sulcus is located deep to the marked structure in the image, which is a critical landmark in neuroanatomy for separating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.

questions.text: Identify the structure which is responsible for elevation and is supplied by the nerve emergency from the structure shown in the image? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Risorius

 

Explanation:

 

Risorius is supplied by the facial nerve, resulting in the marked elevation. The image depicts the floor of the fourth ventricle, as well as the facial colliculus.

 

 

The facial colliculus is a raised area on the floor of the fourth ventricle in the brainstem, and it is associated with the motor nucleus of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). The facial nerve is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression, including the risorius muscle, which is one of the muscles that can cause elevation of the corner of the mouth in smiling. Therefore, the structure that is supplied by the nerve causing this elevation would be the risorius muscle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral rectus: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring. It is innervated by the abducens nerve.

 

Option B. Superior oblique: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the body of the sphenoid. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.

 

Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle is supplied by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). This muscle is responsible for raising the upper eyelid (levator means "elevator"), allowing you to open your eyes.

 

The oculomotor nerve also innervates several other muscles that control eye movement and pupil constriction, making it an important cranial nerve for eye function

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risorius muscle, responsible for pulling the corner of the mouth laterally and aiding in expressions like smiling, is innervated by the facial nerve.

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. Which of the following is the best representation of compliance between the three lungs? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) В>А>С

 

  • ﻿﻿The above graph is a pressure-volume relationship showing the relationship between the work of breathing and lung mechanics.
  • ﻿﻿The graphs show the lung compliance which is the change in lung volume with change in intrapleural pressure.
  • A steeper curve implies more compliance while a flatter curve implies less compliance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steepness of the pressure-volume curve indicates lung compliance. In this graph, lung B has the highest compliance, lung A has moderate compliance, and lung C has the lowest compliance.

questions.text: A young marathon runner is participating in a marathon competition. After running for 100 m, he develops pain at the anteromedial aspect of tibia which was mild to start with, but increased on further running. X-ray was normal. The doctor ordered a bone scan. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shin splint

 

STRESS/FATIGUE FRACTURE

 

  • Stress fracture is due to imbalance between load and resistance of bone.
  • It is of 2 types:
    1. Fatigue fracture: Caused by application of abnormal stress on normal bone.
    2. Insufficiency fracture: Caused by normal activity on weak bone.
  • Sites of Stress Fractures:
    1. Lower Extremity:
      • March fracture is a stress fatigue fracture of second metatarsal neck > 3rd metatarsal neck. The most common site is metatarsal neck followed by tibia (proximal third in children, middle third in athlete and lower third in elderly).
      • Tibia stress fracture = Shin splints
      • Femoral neck (inferomedial compression side in young and superior tension side in older patients).
      • Rarely fibula lower end (runner’s fracture).
    2. Upper Extremity:
      • Olecranon is most common site of upper limb stress fractures.
    3. Pelvis and Spine:
      • Pars interarticularis of 5th lumbar vertebral (causing spondylolysis) is commonest in spine.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Load related pain often bilateral
    • The hallmark physical finding is tenderness with palpation and stress.
  • Investigation:
    • MRI provides excellent sensitivity and superior specificity compared to bone scan in differentiating from infections or tumors.
    • Bone scan is preferable for bilateral cases due to feasibility, also bilateral cases go in favour of stress fracture as compared to Infection or tumor and also can scan the whole body.
  • Treatment: Symptomatic with cast and cessation of activity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lisfranc fracture. A Lisfranc dislocation is a spectrum of injuries involving the tarsometatarsal joints of the foot. The Lisfranc joint is composed of the articulation between the first, second, and third metatarsals bones, and the cuneiform bones. Injury of the joint can range from complete tarsometatarsal displacement with associated fractures and ligamentous tears to partial sprains with no displacement. Lisfranc injuries are uncommon and are often misdiagnosed. Even when recognized and treated promptly, there is still a high risk for chronic disability and complications. There are two main mechanisms of injury: direct, and indirect. A direct mechanism occurs as a crush injury to the joint from motor vehicle collision or industrial accident. An indirect injury is more common and is often associated with sports participation involving a longitudinal force with the foot in plantarflexion with a medial or lateral rotational force. The patient presents with complaint of midfoot pain with weight-bearing, following an acute injury. The pain worsens by forefoot weight bearing, and the patient may describe pain or difficulty with the push-off phases of walking and/or running. There is pain with abduction and eversion of the forefoot. Pain can also commonly be reproduced with passive pronation or supination of the tarsometatarsal joint. Radiographic findings show misalignment of the lateral margin of the first metatarsal base with the lateral edge of the medial cuneiform, misalignment of the medial aspect of the second metatarsal base with the medial edge of the middle cuneiform, and/or small avulsion fragments a one of metatarsal or cuneiform bones. On oblique view, the medial aspect of the cuboid should line up with the medial aspect of the fourth metatarsal base. The dorsal cortex of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform should be aligned on the lateral radiographs. Lisfranc injuries can be managed operatively. Initial treatment includes reduction, splinting, and elevation. After six weeks, if the patient is non-tender and radiographs are negative, then begin weight-bearing and rehabilitation. If there is any tenderness but no displacement, then the patient should be in a boot or cast for at least another four weeks before starting rehabilitation. Any displacement requires surgical fixation.

 

 

Option B. Jones fracture. A Jones fracture is a fracture of the proximal metadiaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal bone that involves the 4th-5th metatarsal articulation. The fracture occurs as a result of significant adduction force to the forefoot with the ankle in plantar flexion. On a plain radiograph, Jones fracture is located at the metadiaphyseal junction, approximately 2 cm (1.5-3 cm) from the tip of the 5th metatarsal and has a predominantly horizontal course. It should not extend distally. Jones fractures are particularly prone to non-union due to being in a vascular watershed zone and take longer than two months to heal. Displacement of the fracture can increase with persistent weight-bearing; therefore, immobilization is important, with a non-weight bearing cast for 6-8 weeks. Indications for non-operative management include undisplaced fractures and fractures in patients with limited activity (i.e. recreational athletes). Operative management is indicated in patients that are elite or competitive athletes or when delayed union has occurred. Management includes either intramedullary screw fixation or open reduction and internal fixation. 

 

 

Option D. Nutcracker fracture. A nutcracker fracture refers to a cuboid bone fracture with associated navicular avulsion fracture due to compression between the bases of 4th and 5th metatarsals and calcaneus bone. The injury usually occurs secondary to the traumatic abduction of the forefoot. This results in loss of the normal lateral column support and excess valgus force upon the medial column that commonly causes rupture of tibialis posterior tendon or avulsion fracture of its attachment onto medial aspect of the tarsal navicular bone. Nutcracker fractures are clinically significant because they can interfere with the medchanical alignment of the foot.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Shint splint or stress fracture of tibia is the most common injury in runners.

questions.text: Fibres of the given structure originate from? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

The given structure is the fornix and its fibres arise from the hippocampus.

 

The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter fibers that connects the hippocampus to other regions of the brain, including the mammillary bodies, thalamus, and septal nuclei. The fibers of the fornix arise from the hippocampus, which is involved in the formation and consolidation of memories, and then project through the fornix to other parts of the limbic system. Dysfunction of the fornix and hippocampus can result in memory impairments, as seen in conditions such as Alzheimer's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amygdala: The amygdala is a small almond-shaped structure located deep within the temporal lobes of the brain. It is involved in processing emotions, especially fear and emotional memory. While the amygdala does have connections to the limbic system, it is not a direct source of fibers for the fornix. However, it does interact with the hippocampus and other limbic structures.

 

Option B. Mammillary Body: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, round structures located on the undersurface of the brain, specifically in the diencephalon. They are closely connected to the hippocampus and are considered part of the limbic system. The fornix sends fibers to and receives fibers from the mammillary bodies, facilitating the flow of information within the limbic circuit.

 

Option C. Caudate Nucleus: The caudate nucleus is a component of the basal ganglia and is involved in motor control and cognitive functions. While it interacts with some limbic structures, it is not a primary source of fornix fibers. Instead, it has connections with other regions involved in motor control and reward processing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hippocampus is a critical structure within the limbic system that plays a central role in memory formation and spatial navigation. It is the primary source of fibers that make up the fornix. The fornix carries information from the hippocampus to other limbic structures, including the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nuclei, as well as to the septal nuclei and the cingulate gyrus.

questions.text: Structure which is related deep to marked structure? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stem of lateral sulcus

 

The marked structure in the image is the pterion, which is an H-shaped area on the lateral side of the skull where four bones meet (frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid). The central part of the pterion is called the Sylvian point. Deep to the pterion lies the stem of the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure) of the brain. The pterion is a clinically important landmark because the middle meningeal artery runs directly beneath it, and injury to this area can cause extradural hemorrhage, which appears as a biconvex opacity on radiological imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ICA Siphon: Incorrect because the internal carotid artery (ICA) siphon is located deeper in the skull, within the cavernous sinus, not directly beneath the pterion.

 

Option C. Wernicke's area: Incorrect because Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus (area 22) of the dominant hemisphere, not directly deep to the pterion.

 

Option D. Pineal gland: Incorrect because the pineal gland is located at the center of the brain in the epithalamus, not related to the pterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H-shaped area on the lateral skull where four bones meet (frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid), and it overlies the stem of the lateral sulcus and middle meningeal artery.

choices.text: Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for vaginal delivery
Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency cesarean delivery is available
Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labour
Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

questions.text: A woman in labour presented to the ER. A vaginal breech delivery was planned for her. What statement regarding the management is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for vaginal delivery 

 

Breech identified for the first time during delivery is not a contraindication for normal delivery.

 

Vaginal Breech Delivery is Considered When:

 

  • Fetal weight is between 1.5 kg and 3.5 kg
  • There is an adequate pelvis
  • The presentation is frank breech
  • The fetal head is flexed
  • There are no medical or obstetric complications
  • Facilities for emergency cesarean section are available (anesthetists, neonatologists) — relates to option B
  • Facilities for continuous labor monitoring are available — relates to option C
  • A skilled obstetrician is present — relates to option D
  • Detailed informed consent has been obtained, explaining the risks of vaginal breech delivery

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency cesarean delivery is available: True. Availability of cesarean facilities is critical for safety.

 

Option C. Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labour: True. Continuous fetal heart rate (FHR) monitoring is essential to ensure fetal well-being.

 

Option D. Should be done by a skilled obstetrician: True. Vaginal breech delivery requires expertise to minimize risks.

 

Educational Objective:


Breech presentation during labour is not an automatic contraindication for vaginal delivery. However, specific criteria must be met, including the availability of emergency cesarean facilities, continuous fetal monitoring, and the presence of a skilled obstetrician.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with an arrow: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary trunk

 

The given image represents a cross-sectional view of the thorax, and the structure marked by the arrow is identified as the pulmonary trunk. The key points to identify the pulmonary trunk are its location and the surrounding structures in the thoracic cross-section.

 

  • Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel that arises from the right ventricle of the heart and bifurcates into the right and left pulmonary arteries. It is situated anterior to the aorta and is clearly visible in the image as a large tube dividing into two branches.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carina: The carina is the point at which the trachea bifurcates into the left and right main bronchi. It is located lower in the thoracic cavity and is not associated with the structures visible in the image.

 

Option B. Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava is located to the right of the sternum and is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option D. Arch of Aorta: The arch of the aorta is the curved portion of the aorta that gives rise to the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. In a cross-sectional view, it appears as an elongated structure, not as the large round structure marked by the arrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel located anterior to the aorta, bifurcating into the right and left pulmonary arteries, and is the structure identified by the arrow in the cross-sectional image of the thorax.

questions.text: All of the following are derivatives of NCC except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinal pigment membrane

 

The retinal pigment membrane (or retinal pigment epithelium, RPE) develops from the ectoderm of the optic cup, which is an outgrowth of the developing brain, and not from neural crest cells. The neural retina and RPE both develop from the neuroectoderm of the optic vesicle, making them extensions of the central nervous system rather than neural crest derivatives.
 

Neural crest cells (NCCs)

Ciliary muscles

Melanocytes

Ciliary ganglion

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ciliary muscles: The ciliary muscles develop from neural crest cells that contribute to the development of structures in the eye.

 

Option C. Melanocytes: Melanocytes throughout the body, including those in the skin and iris, are derived from neural crest cells that migrate from the neural tube during embryonic development.

 

Option D. Ciliary ganglion: The ciliary ganglion, a parasympathetic ganglion associated with the eye, is derived from neural crest cells. Neural crest cells give rise to all parasympathetic ganglia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neural crest cells give rise to diverse structures including melanocytes, parasympathetic ganglia (including ciliary ganglion), and components of the eye (like ciliary muscles), but the retinal pigment epithelium develops from the optic cup neuroectoderm.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The median nerve supplies the 1st lumbrical which is marked.

 

The 1st lumbrical muscle is innervated by the median nerve. It is a small, quadrilateral muscle located in the hand that arises from the tendon of the flexor digitorum profundus muscle of the index finger and inserts into the extensor expansion of the index finger. Its main function is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joint of the index finger and extend the interphalangeal joints of the index finger. The 1st lumbrical muscle is named because it is associated with the first (index) finger, and there are a total of four lumbrical muscles in the hand - one for each of the four fingers (excluding the thumb).

 

The first and second lumbrical nerves are innervated by the median nerve. The third and fourth lumbricals are innervated by the deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial Nerve: The radial nerve primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand, including the wrist and finger extensors. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.

 

Option C. Ulnar Nerve: The ulnar nerve supplies several intrinsic hand muscles, including the lumbrical muscles. However, the first lumbrical is typically innervated by the median nerve, as mentioned earlier.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous Nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve primarily innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 1st lumbrical muscle of the hand is innervated by the median nerve is crucial for clinical assessments of hand function, especially in cases of nerve injury or compression syndromes like carpal tunnel syndrome, where the median nerve's functionality can be compromised.

questions.text: Which nerve does the marked structure contain? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV

 

The marked structure in the image is the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV), which is the thinnest cranial nerve. It is located in the area near the midbrain, passing around the lateral side of the brainstem before entering the cavernous sinus. The trochlear nerve is unique among cranial nerves as it emerges from the dorsal surface of the brainstem (posterior aspect) and is the only cranial nerve that completely decussates before innervating its target structure, the superior oblique muscle of the contralateral eye.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is the thinnest cranial nerve, emerges from the dorsal midbrain, completely decussates, and supplies only the superior oblique muscle of the contralateral eye.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tributary of the inferior vena cava? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left inferior phrenic vein

 

 

The left inferior phrenic vein is a direct tributary of the inferior vena cava. Both the right and left inferior phrenic veins drain into the inferior vena cava.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left suprarenal vein: The left suprarenal vein does not drain directly into the inferior vena cava. Instead, it drains into the left renal vein, which then drains into the inferior vena cava.

 

Option C. Left gonadal vein: Similar to the left suprarenal vein, the left gonadal vein (whether it is the testicular vein in males or the ovarian vein in females) drains into the left renal vein before it reaches the inferior vena cava.

 

Option D. Right ascending lumbar vein: The right ascending lumbar vein is not a direct tributary of the inferior vena cava. It usually joins with the subcostal vein to form the azygos vein on the right side, which then drains into the superior vena cava.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tributaries of the inferior vena cava include veins that drain directly into it without first passing through another vein, except for the hepatic veins.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrectly matched pair(s) of pharyngeal arch and its artery?

 

  1. 1st arch - Maxillary artery
  2. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery
  3. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery
  4. 4th arch - Subclavian artery
  5. 6th arch - Aorta on the left side
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. v

 

Explanation

 

All the given pairs of pharyngeal arteries and their arteries are correctly matched except for 'v' (option C).

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch has its blood supply on the left side from the left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus, not from the aorta.

 

Other options

 

  1. 1st arch - Maxillary artery: Correct. The maxillary artery is indeed a derivative of the first pharyngeal arch.
  2. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery: Correct. The hyoid artery (or the stapedial artery in its embryonic context) is derived from the second pharyngeal arch.
  3. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery: Correct. The third pharyngeal arch gives rise to portions of the common carotid artery and the proximal part of the internal carotid artery.
  4. 4th arch - Subclavian artery: Correct on the right side. The fourth pharyngeal arch is associated with the development of the right subclavian artery and part of the aortic arch on the left side.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Which skull foramen is formed by 3 bones?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Foramen lacerum

 

Explanation:

 

The foramen lacerum is a triangular-shaped foramen located in the skull base. It is largely filled with cartilage in a living individual and serves as a landmark rather than a conduit for significant neurovascular structures (though some smaller emissary veins and nerves might pass through). Importantly, the internal carotid artery courses superiorly to this foramen but doesn't pass through it. The foramen lacerum is bordered by three bones:

 

  • Petrous part of the temporal bone: This bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • Sphenoid bone: The greater wing of the sphenoid bone forms the anterior and lateral aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • Basilar part of the occipital bone: The basilar part of the occipital bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.

 

The foramen lacerum is covered by a fibrous membrane, which makes it difficult to see and access.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foramen magnum: The foramen magnum is the largest foramen of the skull and is located in its base. Through it pass the medulla oblongata (which becomes the spinal cord as it exits the skull), the vertebral arteries, spinal parts of the accessory nerves, and the anterior and posterior spinal arteries. It is formed entirely by the occipital bone.

 

Option C. Foramen rotundum: The foramen rotundum is located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. Through this foramen, the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve (V2) exits the cranial cavity to enter the pterygopalatine fossa. It is formed solely by the sphenoid bone.

 

Option D. Foramen jugulare (jugular foramen): The jugular foramen is a large irregular opening located between the petrous part of the temporal bone and the occipital bone. This foramen transmits the internal jugular vein and several cranial nerves: the glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), and accessory (XI) nerves. It is formed by two bones:

 

  1. Anterolaterally: the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  2. Posteromedially: the occipital bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The foramen lacerum's formation by three bones (the petrous part of the temporal bone, greater wing of the sphenoid bone, and basilar part of the occipital bone) makes it unique among the foramina at the base of the skull. Understanding its anatomical context and relations is crucial for interpreting imaging and planning surgeries involving the cranial base.

questions.text: Primary follicles arrest in which phase of prophase 1? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diplotene

 

Primary follicles containing primary oocytes are arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase I of meiosis. This arrest occurs before a female is born and remains until puberty. The mnemonic "PPD" can help remember this: Primary oocyte, Prophase I, Diplotene stage. After puberty, under hormonal influence during each menstrual cycle, selected primary oocytes resume meiosis, complete the first meiotic division to form secondary oocytes, and then arrest again at metaphase II until fertilization occurs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leptotene: Incorrect because leptotene is an earlier stage of prophase I where chromosomes begin to condense and become visible. Primary oocytes progress beyond this stage before arresting.

 

Option B. Zygotene: Incorrect because zygotene is the stage where homologous chromosomes begin to pair up (synapsis). Primary oocytes progress beyond this stage before arresting.

 

Option C. Pachytene: Incorrect because pachytene is the stage where crossing over (genetic recombination) occurs between homologous chromosomes. Primary oocytes progress beyond this stage before arresting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary oocytes remain arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase I of meiosis from before birth until puberty, resuming meiosis only when stimulated by hormones during the menstrual cycle.

questions.text:
Arrange in sequence the structures involved in the direct pathway: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1. Striatum

2. Globus pallidus

3. Substantia nigra

4. Thalamus

5. Cortex
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 5,1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

The correct sequence is as follows:

 

5. Cortex - provides the initial input to the basal ganglia.

 

1. Striatum - receives input from the cortex and is the first structure in the basal ganglia circuitry.

 

2. Globus pallidus - receives inhibitory input from the striatum and projects to the thalamus.

 

3. Substantia nigra - provides dopaminergic input to the striatum.

 

4. Thalamus - receives excitatory input from the globus pallidus and projects back to the cortex to complete the loop.

 

The basal ganglia needs the input from the cortex in order to act. The first and last component of the pathway is always the cerebral cortex. 


The complete pathway is Cortex/ Thalamus/ brain stem to stratum, then to globus pallidus & substantia nigra then to thalamus and then back to cortex.


Hence out of the available options 5,1,2,3,4 is the best suitable.

 

 

 

The putamen is located laterally and the internal capsule is located medially to the pallidum. The striatum and subthalamic nuclei send fibres to it. It is the primary basal ganglia output to the thalamus and superior colliculus. Each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri contains the substantia nigra. Dopamine levels in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of structures in the direct pathway of the basal ganglia starts with the cortex and follows through the striatum, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and ends at the thalamus. This pathway is fundamental in processing motor signals, which is particularly relevant in understanding disorders like Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: Superior gluteal nerve supplies all of the following structures except:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Piriformis

 

All of the structures except pyriformis are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Pyriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis.

 

The superior gluteal nerve is a nerve that originates from the dorsal branches of the L4, L5, and S1 spinal nerves. It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle and provides motor innervation to the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles. The superior gluteal vessels also accompany the nerve.

 

The nerve to the piriformis, on the other hand, arises from the dorsal branches of the S1 and S2 spinal nerves. It passes through or underneath the piriformis muscle and provides motor innervation to the piriformis muscle itself.

 

Damage or compression to the superior gluteal nerve can result in weakness or atrophy of the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles, leading to difficulty with hip abduction and stabilization. Compression of the nerve to the piriformis can result in piriformis syndrome, a condition in which the piriformis muscle irritates or compresses the nerve, causing pain and numbness in the buttock and leg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluteus medius: The superior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus medius muscle. This muscle is important for hip abduction and stabilization of the hip joint, especially during activities like walking and running.

 

Option B. Gluteus minimus: Similar to the gluteus medius, the superior gluteal nerve also supplies the gluteus minimus muscle. This muscle is located deep to the gluteus medius and assists in hip abduction and stabilization.

 

Option D. Tensor fasciae latae: The superior gluteal nerve supplies the tensor fasciae latae muscle. This muscle helps in flexing, abducting, and medially rotating the hip joint. It also assists in stabilizing the pelvis when standing on one leg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The piriformis muscle is not supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Instead, it is primarily innervated by the branches of the sacral plexus, specifically the ventral rami of S1 and S2. The piriformis muscle plays a role in external hip rotation.

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with the following Skin Manifestation of a Disease associated with Raynaud Phenomenon. What is the manifestation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Salt and Pepper Pigmentation

 

Option B: Salt and Pepper Pigmentation

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Systemic Sclerosis, and the skin manifestation shown is a Salt-and-Pepper Appearance.

 

  • An autoimmune condition with a complex pathogenesis, variable clinical presentations, and an unknown etiology is systemic sclerosis.
  • Significant disability and mortality are linked to it.
  • Almost all organs are impacted. Scleroderma, or thickened and indurated skin, is the defining characteristic of systemic sclerosis.
  • The typical white discoloration of the fingers brought on by vasospasm and the bluish discoloration of the fingertips are Raynaud phenomenon (first symptom) skin characteristics of systemic sclerosis.
  • The skin has a salt-and-pepper appearance when there is a loss of pigmentation, which is most noticeable on the upper back (as given in the question), chest, and scalp.
  • 4: 1 female predominance
  • Sclerodactyly and sclerosis extending proximal to the metacarpophalangeal joints with or without contractures.
  • Earliest cutaneous manifestations are non-pitting oedema and puffiness
  • Severe flexion contractures & Muscle weakness
  • Loss of fingertip pulp
  • Loss of sweat glands in distal extremities
  • Vasculopathic ulcers over the bony prominences
  • Expressionless facies, mat-like telangiectasias, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and a beak-like nose
  • Pruritus correlates with severity of cutaneous sclerosis
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease.
    • Interstitial lung disease is common in patients with Scl-70 antibodies
    • Nucleolar pattern of IF (some spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and it represents antibodies to RNA) is seen in systemic sclerosis.
    • Systemic sclerosis specific autoantibodies: anti-topoisomerase, anti-centromere and anti-RNA polymerase
    • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis or CREST syndrome: Anti-Centromere antibodies

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Poikiloderma is a skin disorder characterized by: (ATP)

 

  • Atrophy
  • Telangiectasias
  • Pigment abnormalities Hypo and hyper

 

It is seen in ionizing radiation-damaged skin and dermatomyositis.

 

Option C. Sometimes the colour of the hair can change to white in the amelanotic lesions of vitiligo. It is known as Leucotrichia.

 

Option D. Sharply demarcated depigmented macules are a hallmark of vitiligo. It results from the loss of melanocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

'Salt and pepper' pigmentation is a skin manifestation associated with systemic sclerosis, a condition commonly accompanied by Raynaud's phenomenon. This pattern includes both hyperpigmented and hypopigmented areas interspersed on the skin.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 56 Page No 56.1 – 56.23

questions.text:
Many GPCR receptors act via increase in cAMP. There are several steps involved in this mechanism as given below. Which of the following is correct sequence of events in cAMP signal transduction pathway? (INICET May 2024)

 

Steps involved


1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
2. Activation of PKA
3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
4. Phosphorylation of target proteins
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 2 and 4

 

The correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway is:

 

  1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
  2. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
  3. Activation of PKA
  4. Phosphorylation of target proteins

 

Therefore, the correct answer is: B. 1, 3, 2 and 4

questions.text:
The fibres of the internal oblique muscle and transversus abdominus muscle contribute to which boundaries of the inguinal canal walls? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Anterior wall
  2. Roof
  3. Floor
  4. Posterior wall
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ii and iv

 

 

 

The inguinal canal is an important structure in the anterior abdominal wall, with specific boundaries formed by different layers of muscles and fascia. The internal oblique is present in the lateral 1/3rd of anterior wall but transverse abdominis does not contribute to the anterior wall at all.

 

ii. Roof: The fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, along with their conjoint tendon, form the roof of the inguinal canal.

 

iv. Posterior wall: The conjoint tendon, formed by the joining of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, also contributes to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

i. Anterior wall: The anterior wall of the inguinal canal is primarily formed by the external oblique aponeurosis, along with skin and superficial fascia. The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles do not contribute to the anterior wall.

 

iii. Floor: The floor of the inguinal canal is formed by the inguinal ligament, not by the internal oblique or transversus abdominis muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles contribute to the roof and posterior wall of the inguinal canal through their conjoint tendon.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passing via jugular foramen has a separate canal?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passing through the jugular foramen has a separate canal.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve, and it is responsible for providing sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and certain structures in the head and neck region. It originates in the brainstem, specifically from the medulla oblongata, and has both sensory and motor components.

 

The sensory branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for providing sensation to the back of the tongue, tonsils, pharynx, middle ear, and the carotid sinus (which is a baroreceptor that helps regulate blood pressure). It also plays a role in taste sensation for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

The motor branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for controlling the muscles of the pharynx and the parotid gland, which is a salivary gland located in the cheek. Dysfunction of the glossopharyngeal nerve can result in symptoms such as difficulty swallowing, decreased taste sensation, and a decreased gag reflex.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII): The hypoglossal nerve passes through the hypoglossal canal, which is a separate opening located just anterior to the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the muscles of the tongue.

 

Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X): The vagus nerve is another cranial nerve that passes through the jugular foramen. It does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. The vagus nerve has numerous functions, including control of the heart, lungs, and digestive organs.

 

Option D. Accessory Nerve (CN XI): The accessory nerve enters the jugular foramen alongside the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves. It also does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve is unique among the nerves passing through the jugular foramen as it occupies a separate canal. Understanding this anatomical detail is vital for surgical navigation and for diagnosing nerve pathologies that may affect swallowing, taste, and autonomic functions in the neck and head region.

questions.text: Which nerve is not the content of superior orbital fissure? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) II

 

The optic nerve (cranial nerve II) does not pass through the superior orbital fissure. Instead, it enters the orbit through a separate opening called the optic canal, along with the ophthalmic artery. The superior orbital fissure transmits structures that supply the eyeball and surrounding tissues, but the optic nerve has its dedicated canal due to its embryological development and functional importance.

 

"LFT" 

 

  • L for Lacrimal nerve
  • F for Frontal nerve
  • T for Trochlear nerve (CN IV)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. III: Incorrect because the oculomotor nerve (CN III) passes through the superior orbital fissure within the common tendinous ring. Its superior and inferior divisions enter the orbit through this fissure.

 

Option C. IV: Incorrect because the trochlear nerve (CN IV) passes through the lateral part of the superior orbital fissure, outside the common tendinous ring, along with the lacrimal and frontal nerves.

 

Option D. VI: Incorrect because the abducent nerve (CN VI) passes through the superior orbital fissure within the common tendinous ring, as part of the mnemonic "SONIA" (Superior division of oculomotor, Nasociliary, Inferior division of oculomotor, Abducent).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior orbital fissure transmits cranial nerves III, IV, VI, V1 (including lacrimal, frontal, and nasociliary branches), and associated vessels, while the optic nerve (CN II) passes through the separate optic canal.

questions.text: Which of the following is a function of the marked layer? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium and water retention

 

The image shows the adrenal gland, which is divided into the cortex and the medulla. The cortex is further subdivided into three layers: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis.

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa: This is the outermost layer of the adrenal cortex and is responsible for the production of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone. Aldosterone plays a key role in regulating sodium and water balance in the body, leading to sodium retention and water reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluconeogenesis: Gluconeogenesis is primarily a function of the zona fasciculata, which secretes glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol) that promote glucose synthesis and metabolism.

 

Option C. Increased sex hormones: The zona reticularis is responsible for producing androgens, which are sex hormones. It does not contribute to sodium and water retention.

 

Option D. Immune cell interaction: While glucocorticoids from the zona fasciculata have some immunosuppressive effects, immune cell interaction is not a primary function of the marked layer, which is the zona glomerulosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex is responsible for sodium and water retention through the secretion of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone.

questions.text: A patient cannot identify objects but she can see the color, texture, shape. What is the site of the lesion? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occipital area

 

 

The patient’s symptoms indicate a condition known as visual agnosia, where there is an inability to recognize objects despite having intact vision for color, texture, and shape. This suggests that the primary visual cortex (area 17) is functioning properly, but the secondary visual processing areas (areas 18 and 19) are affected.

 

  • Occipital Area: The occipital lobe, specifically Brodmann areas 18 and 19, are responsible for the higher-order processing of visual information. Lesions in these areas can result in visual agnosia, where the patient can see but cannot interpret or recognize visual stimuli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial parietal area: The medial parietal area is not primarily  involved in visual recognition.

 

Option B. Lateral parietal area: The lateral parietal area is not involved in the direct processing of visual information.

 

Option C. Infra temporal area: The infra temporal area is not involved in the direct processing of visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesions in the secondary visual processing areas (areas 18 and 19) of the occipital lobe can result in visual agnosia, where the patient can see but cannot identify objects.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint marked in the image: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Saddle

 

  • The marked joint in the image is the incudo-malleolar joint, which is a type of saddle joint. This joint is located in the middle ear and involves the malleus and incus bones. The mnemonic "SBI" helps remember the types of joints in relation to the incus:
    • S for Saddle joint (incudo-malleolar joint)
    • B for Ball and socket joint (incudo-stapedial joint)
    • I for the Incus, positioned in front and behind the respective joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ball and socket: Incorrect. The ball and socket joint is found in the incudo-stapedial joint, not the incudo-malleolar joint.

 

Option C. Plane: Incorrect. The plane joint is not represented in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Option D. Gliding: Incorrect. Gliding joints are not present in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The incudo-malleolar joint is a saddle joint, an important anatomical feature in the middle ear.

questions.text: Which of the following childhood injuries will lead to a fish tail injury? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Distal humerus in children

 

  • Fishtail deformity of the distal humerus is a rare delayed complication of distal humeral fractures in children characterized by a contour abnormality of the distal humerus.
  • It results from a non-developing or underdeveloped lateral trochlea.

 

 

  • It has been described after a variety of distal humeral fractures in early childhood, most commonly after supracondylar fractures, or lateral Condyle fractures.
  • If identified in a young child, surgical closure of the medial and lateral portion of the physis may prevent the deformity from progressing and would not cause significant additional humeral length discrepancy.
  • Whilst initially presumed to be a benign condition, long-term follow-up suggests that patients with fishtail deformity are prone to:
    • Functional impairment
    • Ongoing pain
    • Development of early osteoarthrosis

 

Option B. Distal radius. Distal Radius Fractures are the most common site of pediatric forearm fractures and generally occur as a result of a fall on an outstretched hand with the wrist extended. Metaphyseal fractures can be at the volar apex (colle’s fracture) or dorsal apex (Smith’s fracture) or incomplete (torus/buckle fracture). Diaphyseal fracture may involve both bone fracture, plastic deformation or greenstick fracture. Fracture with dislocation includes monteggia and galeazzi fractures.

 

 

Option D. Distal femur. Distal femur fractures in children can have various fracture patterns, including supracondylar fractures, or fractures of any pattern from the Salter-Harris classification.  Salter-Harris II fractures of the distal femur are the most common pattern in children. Even though distal femur fractures are relatively uncommon injuries, they can have significant implications for limb alignment and future growth. Distal femur fractures in children are typically related to trauma, such as falls, motor vehicle accidents, or contact sports. Patients have pain, swelling about the knee, deformity, and an inability to bear weight on the affected leg. Closed manipulation and casting is an option in displaced fractures, although they have significant potential for instability, which could lead to malunion. Internal fixation is the most commonly chosen treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fish tail deformity is a rare complication of distal humerus fracture in children.

questions.text: In a Preoperative surgical safety Checklist, which of the following is not a component? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Signature of the doctor

 

In a preoperative patient surgical safety checklist, doctor's signature is not needed.

 

the signature of the doctor, is not typically a component of the surgical safety checklist. Instead, the checklist focuses on verifying critical safety elements like patient consent, equipment functionality, and instrument sterility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Consent: Ensuring that informed consent has been obtained from the patient is a crucial component of preoperative safety checklists. It confirms that the patient has been informed about the procedure, risks, and alternatives and has given their consent for the surgery.

 

Option C. Functioning pulse oximeter: Checking the functioning of medical equipment like a pulse oximeter is an important step in preoperative safety. It ensures that necessary monitoring devices are in working order to monitor the patient's vital signs during surgery.

 

Option D. Sterility of instruments: Verifying the sterility of surgical instruments is essential to prevent infections during surgery. It ensures that all instruments that will come into contact with the patient are properly sterilized and safe for use.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Z line, A band, H zone, I Band
A band, Z line, H zone, M Band
A band, I Band, Z line, H zone
Z line, A band, M Band, H zone

questions.text: Identify the correct labeling (A, B, C, D) in the given image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Z line, A band, H zone, I Band

 

  • A is the Z line: The light line marking the boundary between sarcomeres
  • B (A band): The darker, thicker region representing myosin filaments
  • C (H zone):  The lighter area between the A bands
  • D (I Band): The lighter area between Z lines containing actin filaments

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.
The left adrenal gland is closely related with the tail of pancreas and spleen.
The adrenal are yellow on gross appearance.
The adrenal are retroperitoneal in location.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the anatomy of the adrenal glands?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.

 

 

  • The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape: This statement is false. The right adrenal gland is actually pyramidal in shape. The left adrenal gland is semi-lunar (crescent-shaped) in shape. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The left adrenal gland is closely related with the tail of pancreas and spleen: This statement is true. The left adrenal gland is anatomically positioned near the tail of the pancreas and the spleen.

 

Option C. The adrenal are yellow on gross appearance: This statement is true. The adrenal glands have a yellowish appearance on gross examination due to their rich lipid content.

 

Option D. The adrenal are retroperitoneal in location: This statement is true. The adrenal glands, like the kidneys, are retroperitoneal, meaning they are located behind the peritoneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The right adrenal gland is pyramidal in shape, while the left adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.

questions.text: Which is not a branch of facial artery in the face?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mental

 

The first part of the maxillary artery gives rise to the mental artery as a terminal branch of the inferior alveolar artery.

 

The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery that runs a tortuous course through the submandibular region of the face, supplying blood to the muscles of facial expression, submandibular gland, and other structures in the face. The facial artery gives rise to several branches, including the superior and inferior labial arteries, which supply blood to the upper and lower lips, respectively. The lateral nasal artery is a branch of the facial artery that supplies blood to the lateral aspect of the nose.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral Nasal: The lateral nasal artery is a branch of the facial artery that supplies blood to the side of the nose.

 

Option C. Superior Labial: The superior labial artery is a branch of the facial artery that supplies the upper lip and surrounding areas.

 

Option D. Inferior Labial: The inferior labial artery is also a branch of the facial artery, and it supplies the lower lip and surrounding regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mental artery is not a branch of the facial artery. Instead, it is a branch of the inferior alveolar artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery. The mental artery supplies blood to the chin and lower lip.

questions.text: Patient affected with acute hepatitis B infection has currently come for follow up. Identify the serological marker marked in the image? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-HBc Ab

 

Anti Hbc Ab are produced against Hepatitis B infection. IgM is produced early and IgG later. Production of antibodies(A) is seen to correspond to gradual reduction of surface, envelop antigens.

 

 

Person recovering from acute infection may have negative anti HbS levels with low HbsAg levels. This is called window period where there is a lag between development of antiHbS and HbsAg levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-HBe Ab: These antibodies against the hepatitis B e antigen generally signify lower levels of viral replication. They are not represented at the marked point in the graph.

 

Option C. Anti-HBs Ab: These antibodies indicate recovery and immunity and typically appear after the disappearance of HBsAg, which occurs later than the timeframe shown for the marked serological marker.

 

Option D. HBsAg: This is the earliest detectable viral antigen to appear in the blood following infection but declines as Anti-HBc Ab and later Anti-HBs appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-HBc antibodies are crucial in diagnosing hepatitis B infection, as they appear early after exposure and persist throughout the infection. They are typically seen during the "window period" when HBsAg starts to wane and before Anti-HBs becomes detectable, indicating the body's initial immune response to the infection.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Hepatology/Viral hepatitis/ chap 339/

questions.text:
When asked the patient to stand on left foot, right side went down. Which structures are involved in this case? (INICET NOV 2023)

 

 

 

  1. Superior gluteal nerve
  2. Gluteus minimus
  3. Gluteus medius
  4. Sciatic nerve
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

 

 

This question describes a clinical scenario where a patient is exhibiting a positive Trendelenburg sign. When asked to stand on the left foot, the patient's right side drops, indicating a problem with the muscles or nerves responsible for maintaining hip stability. The Trendelenburg sign indicates weakness or paralysis of the muscles innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

 

1. Superior Gluteal Nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles. Damage to this nerve can lead to weakness in these muscles.

 

2. Gluteus Minimus: This muscle, along with the gluteus medius, helps to stabilize the pelvis during walking. Weakness or paralysis of the gluteus minimus results in the inability to maintain a level pelvis.

 

3. Gluteus Medius: This muscle is crucial for hip abduction and pelvic stabilization. Weakness or paralysis causes the pelvis to drop on the side opposite to the stance leg.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve does not innervate the gluteus medius or minimus. Its primary functions involve the muscles of the posterior thigh and lower leg. Damage to the sciatic nerve would not cause a Trendelenburg sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Trendelenburg sign, where the pelvis drops on the opposite side when standing on one foot, indicates weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

questions.text: The instrument shown below is used for estimating for hemoglobin levels. What does it measure? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acid hematin

 

The instrument shown in the image is a Sahli’s Hemoglobinometer, which is used to estimate hemoglobin levels in the blood. The principle of this method is based on the conversion of hemoglobin into acid hematin.

 

PRINCIPLE OF SAHLI’S HEMOGLOBINOMETER

 

Blood is mixed with an acid solution so that hemoglobin is converted to brown-colored acid hematin. This is then diluted with water till the brown color matches that of the brown glass standard. The hemoglobin value is read directly from the scale.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sahli’s Hemoglobinometer estimates hemoglobin levels by converting hemoglobin into acid hematin, which is then compared to a color standard.

choices.text: Radical cure of Plasmodium vivax
Prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy
Treatment of severe falciparum malaria
Treatment of endemic malaria in children < 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following is clinical use of tafenoquine? (AIIMS Nov 2019
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Radical cure of Plasmodium vivax

 

Radical cure – Several patients of P. vivax malaria relapse due to persistence of exo-erythrocytic stage. Drugs which attack this stage (hypnozooites) given together with a clinical curative achieve total eradication of the parasite from the patient's body.

 

Drug of choice for radical cure of vivax and ovale malaria is:

 

  • Primaquine 15 mg daily for 14 days
  • Tafenoquine is a new long-acting exo-erythrocytic schizontocidal drug. It has been developed as a single dose radical cure for vivax malaria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy: Tafenoquine is not recommended for malaria prophylaxis in pregnancy due to its potential for causing hemolysis in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Pregnant women are typically advised to use other antimalarial drugs for prophylaxis.

 

Option C. Treatment of severe falciparum malaria: The treatment of severe falciparum malaria typically involves intravenous administration of drugs like artesunate or quinine, rather than tafenoquine. Tafenoquine is not used in this context.

 

Option D. Treatment of endemic malaria in children < 2 years: Tafenoquine is not recommended for use in children under 2 years of age. The safety and efficacy of tafenoquine in this age group have not been established, and alternative antimalarial therapies are preferred for young children.

 

Educational objective:

 

Tafenoquine is used for the radical cure of Plasmodium vivax malaria due to its long-acting effects against the exo-erythrocytic stage of the parasite, helping to prevent relapses.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 878

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roenne's nasal step

 

  • Roenne's nasal step is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma.
  • Roenne's nasal step is a visual field defect. It is the result of two arcuate scotomas running in different arcs and meeting at the horizontal meridian. This forms a right-angled defect in the nasal side of the visual field.

 

Roenne’s nasal step

 

 

  • Early glaucomatous changes:
    • Increase in cup-disc ratio (C/D ratio) to >0.4
    • Splinter hemorrhages near the optic disc margin
    • Atrophy of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Advanced glaucomatous changes:
    • Marked increase in C/D ratio (0.7 or more)
    • Thinning of the neuroretinal rim
    • Nasal shifting of the retinal vessels or bayonetting
    • Pulsations of retinal arterioles at the disc margin.
    • If the damage progresses, all neural tissue is destroyed and the optic nerve appears white and deeply excavated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bayonetting: This refers to the appearance of blood vessels on the optic disc where the vessels appear to sharply bend or 'bayonet' due to the structural changes in the optic disc from glaucomatous damage, particularly as the neuroretinal rim thins and the cup enlarges.

 

Option C. Increased cup-disc ratio: A hallmark of glaucomatous damage to the optic nerve, where the optic cup enlarges relative to the overall disc, often exceeding a ratio of 0.5, which is considered abnormal and suggestive of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Baring of nasal arteries: This describes the exposure or baring of the nasal retinal arteries as a result of thinning of the nerve fiber layer in glaucoma. It is a less commonly described feature compared to others but can occur as part of the broader pattern of optic nerve head changes in glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roenne's nasal step, while indicative of the functional impact of glaucoma, does not represent a direct observation of the optic disc but is rather a manifestation of the disease's effect on the visual field.

choices.text: It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate
It occurs due to the defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge
It contains skin, cartilage and bone
It is a benign tumor of coccyx

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about the clinical pediatric case as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate

 

 

 

The image shows a sacrococcygeal teratoma, which is a tumor located at the base of the coccyx in newborns. It is the most common tumor in neonates, and its origin and characteristics are well understood.

 

  • Persistence of Primitive Streak: Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak, not from the prochordal plate. The primitive streak is a structure in early embryonic development that usually regresses, but if remnants persist, they can lead to the formation of these tumors.
  • Defective Migration of Primordial Cells: This statement is correct as primordial germ cells that fail to migrate properly to the genital ridge can contribute to the formation of teratomas.
  • Contains Skin, Cartilage, and Bone: Teratomas are composed of tissues derived from all three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. Therefore, they can contain a variety of tissue types including skin, cartilage, and bone.
  • Benign Tumor of Coccyx: Sacrococcygeal teratomas are generally benign, although they can sometimes be malignant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge: This statement is correct. Defective migration can result in teratomas.

 

Option C. Contains skin, cartilage, and bone: This statement is correct as teratomas can contain these tissues.

 

Option D. Benign tumor of coccyx: This statement is correct as sacrococcygeal teratomas are often benign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak and can contain various tissues including skin, cartilage, and bone. They are typically benign tumors located at the base of the coccyx.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Notochord

 

The marked structure in the image is the notochord, which is a rod-like structure that forms along the midline of the developing embryo. The notochord is derived from the primitive node and extends cranially from the primitive streak. It serves as an embryonic axis, providing structural support and playing a crucial role in the induction of the neural tube formation. Later in development, the notochord largely disappears, but its remnants persist as the nucleus pulposus within the intervertebral discs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primitive streak: Incorrect because the primitive streak appears as a linear structure at the caudal end of the embryo and is the site where epiblast cells migrate to form mesoderm and endoderm. It defines the cranio-caudal axis but is not the central rod-like structure shown in the image.

 

Option C. Neural groove: Incorrect because the neural groove is the midline depression that forms as the neural plate folds inward during neurulation. It is wider and more superficial than the notochord and eventually closes to form the neural tube.

 

Option D. Neural crest cells: Incorrect because neural crest cells are populations of cells that form at the lateral edges of the neural plate and migrate throughout the embryo to form various structures. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The notochord is a midline rod-like structure that induces formation of the neural tube, defines the embryonic axis, and later forms the nucleus pulposus of intervertebral discs.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.
The Assertion is true, but the Reason is false.
Both Assertion and Reason are false.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Malathion is used as an ultra-low volume fogger during epidemics.


Reason (R): Ultra-low volume foggers have no residual effects.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Assertion is true, but the Reason is false.

 

Malathion is indeed used as an ultra-low volume (ULV) fogger during epidemics, particularly for vector control, as it helps control mosquito populations effectively. However, the statement in the Reason is incorrect. Ultra-low volume foggers, including Malathion, can leave residual effects. Malathion has residual action that lasts up to approximately 3 months, which makes it useful in epidemic control for an extended period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malathion is preferred as an ultra-low volume fogger due to its low toxicity among organophosphates, but it does have residual effects lasting up to 3 months.

questions.text: A child lacks thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Defective development of which of the following structures is likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario presented here is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. This condition is caused by a defect in the development of the third pharyngeal pouch, denoted as 3.

 

DiGeorge syndrome, also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, is a genetic disorder caused by a missing piece of chromosome 22. It is characterized by a wide range of symptoms that can vary in severity, but are typically grouped together using the mnemonic "CATCH-22":

 

C - Cardiac abnormalities, such as ventricular septal defects (VSD) and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

A - Abnormal facies, including a small chin, low-set ears, and wide-set eyes.

 

T - Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia, leading to a weakened immune system.

 

C - Cleft palate or other palate abnormalities.

 

H - Hypocalcemia or low levels of calcium due to underdeveloped or missing parathyroid glands.

 

22 - Refers to the chromosome 22q11.2 deletion, which causes the syndrome.

 

Other features that may be associated with DiGeorge syndrome include developmental delays, learning disabilities, behavioral problems, and psychiatric disorders. Treatment usually involves managing the individual symptoms and providing support to address any developmental or behavioral challenges

 

  • Cleft palate
  • Abnormal facies
  • Hypocalcemia, secondary to parathyroid aplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (1 - first pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, primarily associated with the development of structures like the middle ear and Eustachian tube.

 

Option B (2 - second pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, related to formations such as the palatine tonsils.

 

Option D (4 - fourth pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, although related to the development of superior parathyroid glands, it is not primarily responsible for the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands like the third pouch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Derivatives of the Pharyngeal Pouches

 

 

The third pharyngeal pouch's proper development is crucial for the normal formation of the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Disruption in this development can lead to significant clinical symptoms like those seen in DiGeorge syndrome, emphasizing the need for genetic testing and comprehensive clinical management in affected individuals.

choices.text: T cell rich B cell lymphoma

questions.text: A young male presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. The biopsy of the lymph node showed RS cells with vague nodule formation and a background of reactive T-lymphocytes. The cells were positive for CD20, LCA, EMA and negative for CD15 and CD30. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nodular Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL)

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL).

 

Axial group (cervical) lymphadenopathy and along with the L&H variant of Reed-Sternberg cells is characteristic.

 

RS cells are neoplastic giant cells. In NLPHL, the cells have vague nodular formation. Immunophenotyping is positive for CD20 (B cell-associated), LCA (CD45), EMA (epithelial marker), and negative for CD15 (monocyte or macrophage-associated) and CD30 (activation marker).

 

 

 

  • TYPES OF RS CELLS:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular Sclerosis - Hodgkin Lymphoma: This subtype of classical Hodgkin lymphoma (CHL) typically shows RS cells that are positive for CD15 and CD30 but negative for CD20, which is the opposite of what is seen in NLPHL.

 

Option B. CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia): CLL is characterized by small, mature-looking lymphocytes in the blood and bone marrow, not by the presence of RS cells or the nodular pattern seen in NLPHL.

 

Option C. T cell rich B cell lymphoma: This is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that could show a nodular pattern, but it lacks the characteristic L&H cells and the immunophenotypic profile seen in NLPHL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nodular Lymphocyte Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL) is characterized by the presence of L&H cells, vague nodular formation, and a specific immunophenotypic profile (CD20+, CD45+, EMA+, CD15-, CD30-), which differentiates it from classical Hodgkin lymphoma and other lymphomas.

choices.text: b, d and e only
c and e only
a and c only
Only e is correct

questions.text:
Mention the true statement/s about drug resistant malaria: (AIIMS May 2019)

 

  1. It is not present in India.
  2. Quinine with clindamycin or doxycycline is still effective treatment.
  3. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective.
  4. Artemether with lumefantrine is useful.
  5. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is not useful due to high risk of recrudescence.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. b, d and e only

 

  • Plasmodium falciparum is now the most common cause of malaria as well as most common cause of drug resistant malaria in India (Option a is false)
  • DOC for multiple drug resistant P falciparum is artemisinin compounds, but they are short acting. The short action is responsible for recrudescence when used as monotherapy in malaria. So they are combined with long acting drugs (known as ACT; Artemisinin based Combination Therapy) like 
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North-Eastern states.
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine/Pyrimethamine: DOC all over India except NE states.
  • Artemisinin’s are contraindicated in first trimester of pregnancy; but can be given in second and third trimester.
  • So, if drug resistant malaria occurs in 1st trimester of pregnancy, DOC is Quinine. To reduce its toxicity, we commonly add clindamycin (in pregnancy and children) or doxycycline (in other patients).
