  • Chloroquine is not effective in drug resistant malaria. So artesunate (not Chloroquine) is combined with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (Option c)  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is not present in India. False. Drug-resistant malaria is present in India. Plasmodium falciparum, known for drug resistance, is a common cause of malaria in India.

 

Option C. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective. False. Chloroquine is not effective in drug-resistant malaria. Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug-resistant malaria in India is effectively treated with ACTs like Artemether with lumefantrine. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is avoided due to the risk of recrudescence.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/876-877

questions.text: A female patient having frothy vaginal discharge was found to have a strawberry cervix. Which of the following is the drug of choice? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:


The description of a frothy vaginal discharge and a "strawberry cervix" is characteristic of trichomoniasis vaginalis, a common sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. The drug of choice for treating trichomoniasis is Metronidazole. This medication can be administered as a single high dose (2g) or in a lower dose (200mg three times daily for 7 days).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fluconazole: This drug is used for treating candidiasis (yeast infections), not trichomoniasis. Candidiasis typically presents with a curdy white discharge rather than frothy discharge and is not associated with a strawberry cervix.

 

Option C. Tetracycline: Tetracycline is an antibiotic used for various bacterial infections but is not effective against trichomoniasis. It is not the drug of choice for treating this parasitic infection.

 

Option D. Cefixime: Cefixime is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections like gonorrhea. It is not effective against trichomoniasis and thus is not appropriate for this condition.

 

 

Educational Objective:


The drug of choice for treating trichomoniasis vaginalis, which presents with frothy vaginal discharge and strawberry cervix, is Metronidazole.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the organism shown below, which causes effacement and attachment of intestinal cells? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EPEC

 

Attachment and effacement lesions on intestinal cells are caused by enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC).

 

EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to the formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.

 

Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

 

  • Bundle-forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  • Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ETEC: ETEC is known for causing watery diarrhea via enterotoxins but does not cause the attachment and effacement lesions seen with EPEC.

 

Option B. EIEC: EIEC causes invasive disease and dysentery by invading and destroying epithelial cells, but it does not cause attachment and effacement lesions.

 

Option D. EHEC: EHEC causes hemorrhagic colitis and can lead to hemolytic-uremic syndrome through the production of Shiga toxin, but it does not cause the effacement and attachment of intestinal cells as EPEC does.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the content of given vacutainer? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clot activator

 

The plastic tube shown in the given image has a red stopper, hence it contains clot activator

 

Red stopper plastic tubes contain silica as a clot activator.

 

The tubes are inverted five times to initiate the clotting process.

 

Use – Serum Analysis, Serology tests, Blood banks

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na-EDTA: EDTA is an anticoagulant used in tubes with a lavender stopper for hematological tests such as complete blood counts (CBC).

 

Option B. Trisodium citrate: This anticoagulant is used in light blue stopper tubes, primarily for coagulation studies such as PT and APTT.

 

Option C. Na-heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used in tubes with a green stopper, commonly for plasma biochemistry tests.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A woman presents with bleeding since 2 days and abdominal pain. Her LMP was 6 weeks back. An ultrasound shows fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

The correct answer is Ruptured ectopic pregnancy. This condition is an emergency where a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, most commonly in the fallopian tube. As the pregnancy grows, it can cause the tube to rupture, leading to internal bleeding. The classic presentation of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy includes:

 

  • Abdominal pain: Due to the rupture and internal bleeding.
  • Vaginal bleeding: Occurs as a result of the ectopic pregnancy.
  • History of amenorrhea (missed period): Indicates an early pregnancy.
  • Fluid in the pouch of Douglas: This is a key diagnostic clue. The pouch of Douglas is the lowest point of the female pelvis, located between the uterus and the rectum. In the case of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, blood often collects here, visible as fluid on an ultrasound.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placentae: This condition involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, typically occurring in the third trimester. It is characterized by severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a rigid, tender uterus. This scenario does not fit the description of the early pregnancy situation described in the question.

 

Option B. Placenta previa: This condition occurs when the placenta covers the cervix either partially or completely. It typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the second or third trimester, not in the first trimester as described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Missed abortion: A missed abortion refers to a situation where the fetus has died but has not been expelled from the uterus. It usually presents with an absence of fetal heart tones on ultrasound and a uterus that is smaller than expected for gestational age. There would not typically be fluid in the pouch of Douglas, which is more indicative of intraperitoneal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early pregnancy, if a patient presents with abdominal pain, bleeding, and a history of missed periods, with fluid in the pouch of Douglas seen on ultrasound, the most likely diagnosis is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. This condition requires immediate surgical intervention.

questions.text: What is the site of drainage of the structure marked in green?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sphenoethmoidal recess

 

The marked structure in the given image is the sphenoid sinus, and it drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

The paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities within the skull bones. These sinuses are divided into two main groups:

 

  1. Anterior group:
    • These sinuses drain into the middle meatus (Option B) via a common drainage pathway known as the osteomeatal unit.
    • The anterior group includes:
      • Maxillary sinus (antrum of Highmore)
      • Frontal sinus
      • Anterior ethmoidal sinus
  2. Posterior group:
    • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: These open into the superior meatus (Option A).
    • Sphenoid sinus: This sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

The inferior meatus (Option C) contains the opening of the nasolacrimal duct, which is guarded by Hasner's valve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior meatus: The superior meatus receives drainage from the posterior ethmoidal sinuses, but it is not the correct location for the sphenoid sinus drainage.

 

Option B. Middle meatus: The middle meatus is the drainage site for the maxillary, frontal, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses, but not for the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option C. Inferior meatus: The inferior meatus is associated with the nasolacrimal duct, which drains tears from the eye into the nasal cavity. It is not related to the drainage of the sphenoid sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sphenoid sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is located above the superior concha. Understanding the drainage pathways of the paranasal sinuses is important in diagnosing and treating sinus infections and related conditions.

questions.text:
Arrange the structures of the cubital fossa in sequence from medial to lateral? (INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Median nerve

2. Radial nerve

3. Tendon of biceps brachi

4. Brachial artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1,4,3,2

 

Explanation:

 

The structures are arranged in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral as follows:

 

1. Median nerve

2. Brachial artery

3. Tendon of biceps brachii

4. Radial nerve (Superficial Branch of radial nerve)

Mnemonic is MBBR
 

 

 

The cubital fossa is actually a triangular area located on the anterior aspect of the elbow, not the upper forearm. It is bounded by several structures, including:

 

  • The lateral border of the pronator teres muscle, which forms the medial boundary
  • The medial border of the brachioradialis muscle, which forms the lateral boundary
  • The imaginary line connecting the epicondyles of the humerus, which forms the superior boundary
  • The floor of the cubital fossa is formed by the brachialis and supinator muscles, while the roof is formed by the Deep fascia of the skin.
  • The roof of cubital fossa contains Subcutaneous veins which are used for routine phlebotomy procedures. These veins are - median cubital vein, cephalic vein and basilic vein

 

The cubital fossa contains several important structures, including the brachial artery, radial nerve, and median nerve. It is a common site for blood draws and intravenous catheter placement due to the relatively superficial location of the structures and ease of access.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct anatomical sequencing of structures in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral—median nerve, brachial artery, tendon of biceps brachii, and radial nerve—is essential for both anatomical education and practical clinical applications.

questions.text:
Arrange the cells according to their positions from the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules? (INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Spermatogonia

2. Primary spermatocyte

3. Spermatid

4. Spermatozoa

5. Myoepithelial cell
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 5,1,2,3,4

 

From the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules, the cells are arranged in the order of:

 

  • Myoepithelial cells
  • Spermatogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Spermatozoa

 

In the seminiferous tubules, cells are organized in a specific sequence from the basal layer towards the lumen as part of the spermatogenesis process. The order reflects the developmental stages of sperm cells:

 

5. Myoepithelial cells: These cells, located at the basal layer, support the structure and function of the seminiferous tubules.

 

1. Spermatogonia: These are the stem cells located just above the basal membrane, which undergo mitotic divisions to produce more spermatogonia or differentiate into primary spermatocytes.

 

2. Primary spermatocytes:  Situated above the spermatogonia, these cells undergo meiosis I to form secondary spermatocytes.

 

3. Spermatid: Derived from the secondary spermatocytes after meiosis II, these cells are closer to the lumen and undergo spermiogenesis to become spermatozoa.

 

4. Spermatozoa: These are the final, mature male gametes that are nearest to the lumen of the tubule, ready to be released into the reproductive tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

From the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules, the cells are arranged in the order of:

 

  • Myoepithelial cells
  • Spermatogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Spermatozoa

questions.text: Identify the type of gland marked in the image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Holocrine

 

The image shows a sebaceous gland, which is the classic example of a holocrine gland. In holocrine glands, the entire secretory cell disintegrates and becomes part of the secretion. The characteristic appearance of sebaceous glands in histological sections shows empty-looking cells with white spaces because the lipid contents (sebum) are dissolved during the preparation of the slide with organic solvents like acetone and alcohol. This gives sebaceous glands their distinctive "empty" appearance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Merocrine: Incorrect because merocrine glands (also called eccrine glands) release their secretions through exocytosis without cell damage. Examples include sweat glands of the palms and soles. They would appear as coiled tubular structures without the empty cell appearance.

 

Option B. Ecrine: Incorrect because ecrine is another term for merocrine glands, which release their secretions through exocytosis without cell damage, unlike the holocrine pattern seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sebaceous glands are holocrine glands where the entire cell disintegrates to form the secretion, and they appear as "empty" structures in histological sections because their lipid contents are dissolved during slide preparation.

choices.text: Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery
Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery
Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery
Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

questions.text: What is the blood supply of the structure marked with the arrow in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery

 

The corpus callosum is the largest fibre pathway in the brain. The corpus callosum is composed of the rostrum, genu, trunk or body, and splenium.

 

The corpus callosum is a large bundle of nerve fibers that connects the two hemispheres of the brain and allows for communication between them. It is supplied with blood by the anterior cerebral artery and the anterior communicating artery, which are both branches of the internal carotid artery.

 

The anterior cerebral artery supplies blood to the front and top of the brain, including the medial surface of the cerebral hemispheres, which is where the corpus callosum is located. The anterior communicating artery connects the two anterior cerebral arteries and provides additional blood supply to the corpus callosum. Damage to the corpus callosum, such as from a stroke or traumatic brain injury, can disrupt communication between the two hemispheres and lead to a range of neurological symptoms depending on the location and severity of the damage.

 

The corpus callosum is the major commissural pathway connecting the cerebral hemispheres that receives its blood supply from anterior communicating artery, pericallosal artery, and posterior pericallosal artery”.

 

“Pericallosal artery is formed by branches of from anterior and posterior cerebral arteries (Mainly anterior cerebral artery). Pericallosal arteries which are derived from anterior cerebral arteries supply the anterior 4/5th of corpus callosum and posterior 1/5th is supplied by pericallosal artery derived from posterior cerebral artery.”

 

Since the arrow is near the posterior end of body answer is ACommA + ACA
If the arrow was near the anterior end, answer will be ACommA + ACA
If the arrow is on splenium, the answer will be ACA + PCA
 

 

 

   

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery: The anterior cerebral artery does supply the corpus callosum, but the middle cerebral artery does not play a significant role in its blood supply.

 

Option B. Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery: While the anterior cerebral artery supplies the corpus callosum, the posterior cerebral artery primarily supplies the posterior parts of the brain, including the occipital lobes. It doesn't contribute significantly to the blood supply of the corpus callosum.

 

Option D. Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery: Neither the middle cerebral artery nor the posterior cerebral artery is the primary supplier of blood to the corpus callosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corpus callosum's blood supply is primarily provided by the anterior cerebral artery, with additional support from the anterior communicating artery. This knowledge is crucial in understanding potential impacts of circulatory issues within the brain, such as strokes, which could affect interhemispheric communication.

questions.text: While walking, the suspended leg is supported by which muscle on other side? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gluteus medius

 

During walking, when one leg is suspended (swing phase), the pelvis tends to drop on the unsupported side due to gravity. The gluteus medius muscle on the stance side (supporting leg) contracts to prevent this drop, stabilizing the pelvis and maintaining level hips during walking. This action allows for a smooth, efficient gait. When the gluteus medius is weak or paralyzed, the pelvis drops on the unsupported side when walking, resulting in a positive Trendelenburg sign and a characteristic lurching gait.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gluteus maximus: Incorrect because the gluteus maximus is primarily responsible for hip extension, which helps in activities like climbing stairs or rising from a seated position. It doesn't significantly contribute to lateral stability of the pelvis during walking.

 

Option C. Tensor Fascia Lata: While the tensor fascia lata does assist in stabilization of the pelvis, it plays a secondary role to the gluteus medius, which is the primary muscle responsible for pelvic stability during walking because of its size and positioning.

 

Option D. Quadriceps femoris: Incorrect because the quadriceps femoris is responsible for knee extension and is known as the "footballer's muscle" or "kicking muscle." It does not contribute significantly to pelvic stability during the walking cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus medius muscle on the stance leg stabilizes the pelvis during walking, preventing the pelvis from dropping on the suspended leg side (Trendelenburg sign when dysfunctional).

questions.text: An old lady sustained a fall and developed a headache and neurological symptoms a few days later. What is your diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subdural hematoma

 

The given clinical scenario of an elderly individual experiencing a headache and neurological symptoms following a fall is highly suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH). Subdural hematomas occur due to bleeding between the arachnoid membrane and the dura mater, which typically results from the rupture of bridging veins. These veins are more prone to injury in elderly patients due to brain atrophy, which increases the distance the veins need to traverse.

 

Elderly individuals, alcoholics, and patients on anticoagulant therapy are at higher risk for developing subdural hematomas. Often, these injuries are triggered by even minor or trivial trauma.

 

A non-contrast CT scan is the preferred diagnostic modality for detecting a subdural hematoma. On CT imaging, acute SDH appears hyperdense (bright), while chronic SDH appears hypodense (dark).

 

Key features of subdural hematomas on CT include:

 

  • Crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) appearance.
  • Hemorrhage may spread across suture lines (unlike epidural hematomas).
  • Typically unilateral (85% of cases).

 

If the subdural hematoma is large (>1 cm), causes a midline shift >5 mm, or there is a neurological decline (e.g., a drop in Glasgow Coma Scale by two or more points), surgical intervention (craniotomy) is indicated for evacuation of the hematoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multi-infarct dementia (MID): MID is a type of vascular dementia that occurs due to multiple small infarctions or strokes, often leading to cognitive decline and memory loss. This type of dementia is common in the elderly, but it is not associated with trauma or sudden neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Frontal lobe meningioma: Meningiomas are benign brain tumors that arise from the meninges. They usually grow slowly and can cause progressive symptoms depending on their location. Frontal lobe tumors may result in personality changes and cognitive decline but are not related to trauma.

 

Option C. Korsakoff syndrome: Korsakoff syndrome is a memory disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, most commonly seen in alcoholics. It primarily affects the ability to form new memories (anterograde amnesia) and may be accompanied by confabulation. However, this condition is not typically linked to traumatic injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subdural hematoma is caused by the rupture of bridging veins between the dura and arachnoid mater, often due to minor trauma in the elderly or patients on anticoagulants. Diagnosis is confirmed through a non-contrast CT scan, and surgical intervention is required in severe cases with significant mass effect.

questions.text: Identify which of the following structure is a merocrine gland:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Explanation

 

Sweat gland marked 4 is a Merocrine gland.

 

Eccrine and apocrine are the two types of sweat glands. Secretions of the sweat glands are by exocytosis hence they are also known as merocrine sweat glands.

 

Sweat glands, also known as sudoriferous glands (examples of merocrine glands). Eccrine sweat glands, in particular, are merocrine glands. They release sweat directly onto the skin surface through a duct without damaging the gland cells.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Sebaceous Gland: Sebaceous glands are holocrine glands, not merocrine glands. They produce sebum, an oily substance, and the entire gland cell ruptures to release its secretion.

 

Option B. Hair Follicle: Hair follicles are not glands but structures in the skin where hair is produced. They are not involved in glandular secretion.

 

Option C. Dermic Sheath / Connective Tissue: Dermic sheath and connective tissue are not glands and do not produce secretions.

 

Educational Objective

 

Merocrine glands, such as eccrine sweat glands (marked as 4), utilize exocytosis to release sweat onto the skin surface, aiding in temperature regulation and waste excretion without causing harm to the glandular cells. This process highlights the efficient and continuous function of eccrine glands in daily thermoregulation and skin moisture.

questions.text: Apocrine glands are present in which of the following?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Axilla

 

 

 

Apocrine glands are a type of sweat gland that are primarily found in certain areas of the body. These glands release their secretions in response to emotional stress or hormonal changes. They are different from the more common eccrine sweat glands, which are distributed throughout most of the body and are primarily involved in temperature regulation.

 

  • Axilla: Apocrine glands are predominantly located in the axilla (underarm) region. They become active during puberty and release a thicker, milky secretion that can produce body odor when broken down by skin bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Face: The face contains sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands, but not apocrine glands.

 

Option B. Scalp: The scalp contains numerous sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands, but apocrine glands are not typically found in this area.

 

Option C. Palms and soles: The palms and soles have a high concentration of eccrine sweat glands, which are crucial for thermoregulation. Apocrine glands are not found in these regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apocrine glands are primarily found in the axilla (underarm) region and become active during puberty, releasing thicker secretions that can lead to body odor when metabolized by skin bacteria.

questions.text: Which ligament connects medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lisfranc

 

Explanation:

 

The Lisfranc ligament connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal.

 

The ligament that connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal is called the "Lisfranc ligament".

 

The Lisfranc ligament is a strong band of fibrous tissue that connects the medial cuneiform bone to the base of the second metatarsal bone in the foot. It is named after Jacques Lisfranc, a French surgeon who described amputations through this region during the Napoleonic Wars. The Lisfranc joint complex also includes the articulation between the other cuneiform bones and the metatarsals, as well as the tarsometatarsal ligaments and interosseous ligaments. The Lisfranc ligament is important for maintaining stability of the midfoot and for transferring forces from the hindfoot to the forefoot during walking and running. Injuries to the Lisfranc joint can result in significant disability and may require surgery to repair or stabilize the joint.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chopart Ligament: Chopart's ligament is not a well-known ligament in the foot. The term "Chopart joint" typically refers to the midtarsal joint, which includes the articulation between the talus and navicular (talocalcaneonavicular joint) and the calcaneus and cuboid (calcaneocuboid joint). Ligaments associated with these joints help maintain their stability.

 

Option B. Spring Ligament: The spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali of the calcaneus to the navicular bone. It is a vital structure for supporting the arch of the foot and preventing its collapse.

 

Option D. Deltoid Ligament: The deltoid ligament is located on the medial side of the ankle joint. It is a complex ligament that attaches to the medial malleolus of the tibia and connects to various tarsal bones, such as the talus, calcaneus, and navicular. The deltoid ligament plays a significant role in stabilizing the ankle joint and preventing excessive eversion (outward rolling) of the foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lisfranc ligament is specifically associated with the connection between the medial cuneiform and the base of the 2nd metatarsal. It is a strong ligament that helps stabilize the midfoot and prevents dislocation of the tarsometatarsal (TMT) joints. Injury to this ligament is commonly referred to as a Lisfranc injury, which can result from traumatic events like falls or sports injuries.

questions.text:
Which among the following statements is true regarding the course of the mandibular nerve? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint.
  2. Buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus.
  3. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct.
  4. Ophthalmic nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arises in the middle cranial fossa.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2,3

 

Explanation:

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 2: True. The buccal branch, which is indeed a branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, emerges from behind the mandibular ramus. This nerve primarily supplies sensory innervation to the skin over the cheek and buccal mucosa.

 

Statement 3: True. The lingual nerve, a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It famously arcs around the submandibular duct, a notable anatomical feature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 1: Incorrect. The auriculotemporal nerve actually arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, not the anterior division, and it does indeed emerge from behind the temporomandibular joint.

 

Statement 4: Incorrect. The ophthalmic nerve is not a branch of the mandibular nerve. Instead, it is an independent division of the trigeminal nerve (V1), originating from the trigeminal ganglion located in the middle cranial fossa. It is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the forehead, scalp, and parts of the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mandibular nerve's complex branching includes both sensory and motor components that are essential for facial sensation and movements. Understanding its branches, such as the buccal and lingual nerves, and their courses, is critical in dental, surgical, and diagnostic practices.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Abductor hallucis
  2. Flexor digitorum accessorius
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis
  4. First lumbrical
  5. First interossei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 5

 

 

 

The lateral plantar nerve is a branch of the tibial nerve, which innervates various muscles in the sole of the foot. It divides into superficial and deep branches, each supplying specific muscles.

 

  • Flexor Digitorum Accessorius : This muscle assists in the flexion of the toes and is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.
  • First Interossei: The interossei muscles, which include the dorsal and plantar interossei, are responsible for abduction and adduction of the toes. The first interossei is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Abductor hallucis: This muscle is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, not the lateral plantar nerve.

 

3. Flexor hallucis brevis: This muscle is also supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

 

4. First lumbrical: The first lumbrical is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, whereas the second, third, and fourth lumbricals are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral plantar nerve supplies the flexor digitorum accessorius (quadratus plantae) and the first interossei muscles in the foot.

questions.text: A patient not able to chew the food and food stuck between cheeks and teeth. Which muscle weakness is associated with this clinical condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buccinator

 

The buccinator muscle, known as the "whistling muscle," is responsible for keeping food between the teeth and preventing it from accumulating in the vestibule (space between teeth and cheeks) during mastication. It helps press the cheek against the teeth, facilitating the proper movement of food in the oral cavity. When it is weak or paralyzed, as can occur in facial nerve (VII) palsy, food gets trapped between the teeth and cheeks because the muscle cannot properly position the food for chewing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Orbicularis oris: Incorrect because this muscle forms the sphincter of the mouth and is responsible for closing and rounding the lips, not for manipulating food during chewing.

 

Option C. Zygomaticus major: Incorrect because this is the "smiling muscle" that draws the angle of the mouth upward and laterally, not involved in keeping food between the teeth during chewing.

 

Option D. Levator labi superioris: Incorrect because this muscle elevates the upper lip and is not primarily involved in keeping food between teeth during mastication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The buccinator muscle, innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII), is essential for keeping food between the teeth during mastication, and its weakness results in food accumulation between cheeks and teeth.

choices.text: Cryptococcus gatti is Associated with bird droppings
All pathogenic strains are urease positive

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Cryptococcus, except? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CD4 count greater than 500

 

Cryptococcus infection occurs when CD4 counts fall below 100 cells/microliter. This makes option d incorrect as Cryptococcus infections do not occur at CD4 counts greater than 500. The infection is strongly associated with severe immunocompromise, particularly in AIDS patients with very low CD4 counts (<100 cells/μL).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extrapulmonary cryptococcus is AIDS defining: Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis is considered an AIDS-defining illness. When Cryptococcus spreads beyond the lungs in HIV patients, it signifies advanced immunosuppression and meets criteria for AIDS diagnosis.

 

Option B. Cryptococcus gatti is Associated with bird droppings: While Cryptococcus neoformans is the more commonly known species, Cryptococcus gatti is also associated with bird droppings, particularly pigeon excreta. Both species can be found in soil contaminated with bird droppings.

 

Option C. All pathogenic strains are urease positive: All pathogenic strains of Cryptococcus are urease positive. This is an important diagnostic feature used to identify Cryptococcus species in laboratory testing. The urease test helps differentiate Cryptococcus from other yeasts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cryptococcal infections occur at CD4 counts less than 100 cells/microliter, not at counts greater than 500. This is a crucial diagnostic criterion for suspecting cryptococcal infection in HIV/AIDS patients.

questions.text: Posterior interosseous nerve injury causes? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of extension at finger

 

The posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) is the deep branch of the radial nerve that supplies most of the extensor muscles in the posterior compartment of the forearm. When injured, it affects the extension of fingers because it directly supplies the extensor digitorum, which is responsible for finger extension. However, it does not supply three specific muscles of the posterior compartment: anconeus, brachioradialis, and extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRB) - these are supplied by the main radial nerve before it divides. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of supination: Incorrect because supination is performed by both the supinator muscle (supplied by PIN) and the biceps brachii (supplied by musculocutaneous nerve). Even with PIN injury, the biceps can still perform supination, especially in the semiflexed elbow position.

 

Option C. Loss of extension of wrist: Incorrect because some wrist extension is preserved due to the function of extensor carpi radialis longus, which is supplied by the radial nerve proper and not the posterior interosseous branch.

 

Option D. Wrist drop: Incorrect because complete wrist drop requires injury to the main radial nerve. In PIN injury, the extensor carpi radialis longus is spared, allowing some wrist extension to be maintained.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior interosseous nerve (deep branch of radial nerve) supplies all posterior compartment muscles except anconeus, brachioradialis, and extensor carpi radialis longus. Its injury results in finger extension loss while preserving partial wrist extension.

questions.text: Efferent to which nucleus of thalamus from indicated structure in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior

 

 

 

The image shows a coronal section of the brain with the indicated structure being the fornix. The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that acts as a major output tract of the hippocampus. It is involved in the Papez circuit, which plays a key role in the control of memory functions.

 

  • Anterior Nucleus of the Thalamus: The fornix carries signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is an integral part of the Papez circuit, involved in emotional and memory processing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral: The lateral nuclei of the thalamus are involved in sensory relay and integration but are not the primary efferent targets of the fornix.

 

Option C. Ventro-postero-lateral: This nucleus is involved in the relay of sensory information from the body to the brain but is not connected to the fornix.

 

Option D. Pulvinar: The pulvinar nucleus is involved in visual processing and attention, not directly associated with the fornix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fornix transmits signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, playing a crucial role in memory processing within the Papez circuit.

questions.text: Epiblast first migration lead to formation of? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endoderm

 

The first migration of epiblast cells leads to the formation of endoderm. During early embryonic development, cells from the epiblast migrate and form the hypoblast, which becomes the endoderm. This is the first germ cell layer to form in the embryo. The formation of germ layers occurs in sequence: endoderm forms first, followed by mesoderm, and finally ectoderm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ectoderm: Incorrect because ectoderm is the last of the three primary germ layers to form. The remaining cells of the epiblast that don't migrate become the ectoderm after the formation of endoderm and mesoderm.

 

Option C. Mesoderm: Incorrect because mesoderm is the second germ cell layer to form, not the first. It develops when epiblast cells migrate through the primitive streak and form a new layer between the endoderm and the remaining epiblast (which becomes ectoderm).

 

Option D. Notochord: Incorrect because the notochord is derived from specialized mesodermal cells at the primitive node. It forms after the initial germ layer formation and is not the direct result of the first epiblast migration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of germ layer formation during gastrulation is: endoderm (first), mesoderm (second), and ectoderm (third), with the first migration of epiblast cells forming the endoderm.

questions.text: Match the following muscles with their action at shoulder joint: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

A. Latissimus dorsi: This muscle is known as the "stand at ease" muscle, the "climbers muscle," and the "swimmers muscle." It originates from the back and inserts into the front between two major muscles. When it contracts, it causes backward movement, extension, adduction, and medial rotation of the shoulder. Therefore, its action is extension with medial rotation (Action 2).

 

B. Supraspinatus: Located above the spine of the scapula, the supraspinatus muscle, when it contracts, moves the arm away from the midline, which is known as abduction. Hence, its action is abduction (Action 3).

 

C. Infraspinatus: This muscle originates from the back and rotates the arm outward when it contracts, causing lateral rotation. Thus, its action is lateral rotation (Action 4).

 

D. Pectoralis Major (sternal head): Originating from the midline (sternum and clavicle) and inserting into the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus, this muscle, when contracted, causes movement to the front (flexion). Therefore, its action is flexion (Action 1).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Latissimus dorsi is responsible for extension with medial rotation.
  • Supraspinatus is responsible for abduction.
  • Infraspinatus is responsible for lateral rotation.
  • Pectoralis Major (sternal head) is responsible for flexion.

questions.text: Which marked structure causes lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, along with flexion at the knee joint?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in the image are:

 

Option A. 1- Rectus femoris

Option B. 2- Vastus lateralis

Option C. 3- Adductor longus

Option D. 4- Sartorius

 

Sartorius is involved in lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, and flexion at the knee. The structure marked '4' is sartorius.

 

The sartorius muscle is a long, thin muscle that runs down the front of the thigh. It is the body's longest muscle and is sometimes referred to as the tailor muscle because of the position that tailors often adopt while working. The sartorius muscle originates from the anterior superior iliac spine and the upper half of the notch below it, and runs obliquely across the thigh to insert into the superior aspect of the medial surface of the tibial shaft near the tibial tuberosity. It joins the aponeurosis of the gracilis and semitendinosus muscles to form the pes anserinus.

 

The sartorius muscle is responsible for several actions, including flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the thigh, as well as flexion of the leg. Because of its location and actions, it is involved in many activities that require movement of the lower limb, such as walking, running, and climbing stairs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of the anterior compartment of thigh (spinal segments in bold are the major segments innervating the muscle)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of type 2 diabetes is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor used in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus. SGLT2 inhibitors work by blocking the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine. This mechanism of action results in a higher concentration of glucose in the urinary tract, which can promote bacterial growth and lead to an increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: This drug is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity but is not associated with an increased risk of UTIs. Instead, it can cause side effects such as fluid retention, weight gain, and an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: This is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor that increases insulin release and decreases glucagon levels in the bloodstream. It is associated with risks such as pancreatitis and gastrointestinal disturbances but not with an increased risk of UTIs.

 

Option D. Metformin: This is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. Common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., diarrhea) and vitamin B12 deficiency, but it does not increase the risk of UTIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This highlights the importance of monitoring for UTIs in patients prescribed this medication.

questions.text: A patient with oral cancer as shown. What is the T stage? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T4a

 

Based on TNM staging for oral cancer:

 

  • Invasion of the floor of the mouth is considered T4a as per AJCC staging
  • Tumor invading floor of mouth indicates local invasion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T2:

 

  • T2 represents tumor 2-4 cm without deep invasion
  • Does not account for floor-of-mouth involvement

 

Option B. T3:

 

  • T3 represents tumor >4 cm without deep invasion
  • Does not account for local invasion

 

Option D. T4b:

 

  • Represents very advanced local disease
  • Involves masticator space, pterygoid plates, skull base
  • Involves encasement of internal carotid artery
  • These structures not involved in this case

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Invasion of floor of mouth in oral cancer represents T4a disease, indicating moderately advanced but resectable local disease.

questions.text: Identify the structure indicated by the arrow:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory bronchus

 

 

 

The image shows a histological section of the lung with an arrow indicating a structure involved in gas exchange. The key features to identify include the presence of air spaces and the type of epithelium lining these spaces.

 

  • Respiratory Bronchus: This structure is part of the respiratory zone of the lung, where gas exchange occurs. It is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium transitioning to simple squamous epithelium as it progresses into the alveolar ducts and sacs. The respiratory bronchus is characterized by the presence of alveoli arising from its walls, indicating the start of the gas exchange process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar sac: Alveolar sacs are the terminal ends of the respiratory tree where clusters of alveoli are found. They are not the initial structures for gas exchange but are rather the sites where the alveoli are grouped.

 

Option C. Terminal bronchiole: Terminal bronchioles are the last part of the conducting zone and do not participate in gas exchange. They are lined with simple cuboidal epithelium without the presence of alveoli in their walls.

 

Option D. Intrapulmonary bronchiole: Intrapulmonary bronchioles refer to the bronchioles within the lung tissue that are part of the conducting zone and do not participate directly in gas exchange.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The respiratory bronchus is the structure where gas exchange begins in the lung, identified by its simple cuboidal epithelium and the presence of alveoli arising from its walls.

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium

 

  • Glycogen phosphorylase is primarily activated indirectly by calcium ions. An increase in intracellular calcium levels triggers the activation of phosphorylase kinase, which, in turn, activates glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium acts as a secondary messenger to stimulate this cascade of enzymatic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6 Phosphate: Glucose 6-phosphate, a product of glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown), actually inhibits glycogen phosphorylase. It is part of a negative feedback mechanism to prevent excessive glycogen breakdown when glucose levels are sufficient.

 

Option C. Insulin: Insulin does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. Instead, insulin plays a role in promoting glycogen synthesis by activating glycogen synthase and inhibiting glycogen phosphorylase.

 

 

Option D. Glucose: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose signal that glucose is available for energy production, leading to the inhibition of glycogenolysis and glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen phosphorylase is activated indirectly through the calcium signaling pathway, which initiates a series of enzymatic reactions ultimately leading to the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. This mechanism allows the regulation of glycogen breakdown in response to cellular energy needs.

questions.text: Given below is the image of a 33-hour chick embryo. Which of the following is derived from the marked structure? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ribs

 

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the para-axial mesoderm. In the 33-hour chick embryo, the para-axial mesoderm is situated on each side of the neural tube and notochord. This mesoderm divides into segments known as somites. Somites further differentiate into sclerotome, myotome, and dermatome.
  • The sclerotome, derived from the somites, gives rise to the vertebrae and ribs. The para-axial mesoderm is responsible for forming these segmented structures, essential components of the axial skeleton.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kidney: Incorrect. The kidney is derived from the intermediate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option B. Dorsal root ganglion: Incorrect. The dorsal root ganglion is derived from neural crest cells, which are separate from the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option C. Parietal pleura: Incorrect. The parietal pleura is derived from the lateral plate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The para-axial mesoderm forms somites, which give rise to the vertebrae and ribs.
